headline: Sec. Bessent speech, Boeing earnings, housing data: What to Watch
summary: Market Domination anchor Julie Hyman outlines stories to watch on Wednesday, April 23. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent will be speaking at the IIF Global Outlook Forum. A big batch of earnings will be published, including from Boeing (BA), IBM (IBM), AT&T, (T) and Chipotle (CMG). Several Federal Reserve officials will be providing commentary, including from Fed governor Christopher Waller, Chicago Fed president Austan Goolsbee, and Cleveland Fed president Beth Hammack. March new home sales data will be released in the morning, with economists forecasting a rise in sales to 684,000. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Domination here.

headline: Investors Hope for No Surprises as Boeing Reports Earnings
summary: Boeing  quarterly results are coming.  Investors are concerned about depressed earnings amid constrained production, questionable quality, and cost-increasing trade wars.  Investors will want updates about all that, but what they might want most of all is less quarterly volatility.

raw.headline: Investors Hope for No Surprises as Boeing Reports Earnings
raw.summary: Boeing  quarterly results are coming.  Investors are concerned about depressed earnings amid constrained production, questionable quality, and cost-increasing trade wars.  Investors will want updates about all that, but what they might want most of all is less quarterly volatility.

headline: Spirit AeroSystems top engineer to lead Wichita site after Boeing deal closes -letters
summary: (Reuters) -Spirit AeroSystems' chief engineer Sean Black will lead the supplier's site in Wichita, Kansas, after Boeing completes its acquisition of Spirit this year, according to letters to employees on Tuesday from both companies.  U.S. planemaker Boeing last year said it had reached an agreement to acquire the struggling aerostructures manufacturer, which it had spun off two decades ago.  Black will become general manager of Boeing Wichita, and hold responsibilities for parts of Spirit's portfolio in Prestwick, Scotland and Belfast, Northern Ireland, letters from Boeing Commercial Airplanes CEO Stephanie Pope and Spirit CEO Pat Shanahan show.

raw.headline: Spirit AeroSystems top engineer to lead Wichita site after Boeing deal closes -letters
raw.summary: (Reuters) -Spirit AeroSystems' chief engineer Sean Black will lead the supplier's site in Wichita, Kansas, after Boeing completes its acquisition of Spirit this year, according to letters to employees on Tuesday from both companies.  U.S. planemaker Boeing last year said it had reached an agreement to acquire the struggling aerostructures manufacturer, which it had spun off two decades ago.  Black will become general manager of Boeing Wichita, and hold responsibilities for parts of Spirit's portfolio in Prestwick, Scotland and Belfast, Northern Ireland, letters from Boeing Commercial Airplanes CEO Stephanie Pope and Spirit CEO Pat Shanahan show.

headline: Boeing's $10.6B deal, Verizon & 3M earnings: Trending tickers
summary: Here are some of the stocks on the move on Tuesday, April 22. Boeing (BA) is selling portions of its Digital Aviation Solutions business to Thoma Bravo for $10.55 billion. Verizon (VZ) reported better-than-expected first quarter earnings, but its postpaid phone losses rose. 3M (MMM) shares are rising after posting first quarter results that topped Wall Street estimates, though it did warn about the impact of tariffs. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Wealth here.

headline: Takeover Tuesday Takes Shape from Boeing to Barrick
summary: Boeing announced it will sell assets to Thoma Bravo for nearly $11 billion in cash. Nomura agreed to buy an asset management business in its most significant overseas acquisition since Lehman Brothers in 2008, while Barrick exits a mining business, in part to John Paulson. Does this signal more dealmaking? Bloomberg's Liana Baker joined Wall Street Beat on Open Interest with some insight.

Does this signal more dealmaking? Bloomberg's Liana Baker joined Wall Street Beat on Open Interest with some insight.

headline: Boeing Sells Jeppesen Unit in $10.6 Billion Thoma Bravo Deal
summary: Boeing agreed to sell its Jeppesen navigation unit and related assets to Thoma Bravo for $10.6 billion in cash, in a deal that also includes Boeing's ForeFlight, AerData and OzRunways businesses. Benedikt Kammel reports on Bloomberg Television.

headline: GE Aerospace Plans to Offset Tariffs with Cost Cuts, Seek Refunds on Some Duties
summary: GE Aerospace laid out a plan to offset tariffs Tuesday, while keeping its financial outlook unchanged, with some caveats. The jet engine maker said it aims to save $500 million by streamlining operations and seeking refunds for duties it pays on imported parts that are later exported.

headline: Boeing to Sell Portions of Digital Aviation Solutions to Thoma Bravo for $10.55 Billion
summary: Boeing [NYSE: BA] has entered into a definitive agreement to sell portions of its Digital Aviation Solutions business, including its Jeppesen, ForeFlight, AerData and OzRunways assets, to Thoma Bravo, a leading software investment firm. This all-cash transaction is valued at $10.55 billion.

headline: GE Aerospace Beats Earnings Estimates. The Stock Is Falling Anyway.
summary: GE Aerospace  posted solid first-quarter earnings.  The company on Tuesday reported operating profit of $2.1 billion and earnings per share of $1.49 from sales of $9 billion.  Wall Street was looking for an operating profit of $1.9 billion and earnings per share of $1.27 from sales of just under $9.1 billion, according to FactSet.

headline: Buyout firm Thoma Bravo nears deal for Boeing's Jeppesen unit, Bloomberg News reports
summary: The planned sale of Jeppesen is part of CEO Kelly Ortberg's strategy to streamline Boeing's operations and reduce its debt pile by selling non-core assets.  Boeing declined to comment, while Thoma Bravo did not immediately respond to Reuters' request for comment.  Reuters reported last month that Jeppesen, a provider of navigation products and software, had attracted interest from several private equity firms and at least one aerospace supplier, with final bids valuing the unit at over $8 billion.
